title: Spool Mount For Prusa Mendel (608 Bearings)

description.text:
Still got some 608 bearings left from constructing your Prusa mendel? Here is a nice way to get rid of them: Use them for your filament spool mount. No bolts needed! You can squeeze the bearings in by applying a little force. I'm guessing ABS would work better, but PLA also does the trick. I also provided 4mm holes for screws, but you'll probably won't need them.  
This THING is designed for a maximum spool width of 100mm. If you need an other width, just comment. unfortunately I have not figured out the customizer yet...  
Enjoy!

author: Freakazoid

description.text:
There's a piece in my 95 Mustang that fills the slot around the gear selector.  It has a colored part that indicates which gear the car is in.  The car is 20yrs old, and this piece has finally broken into several pieces.  This is a model to replace that piece.  I designed this by measuring off my 95 Mustang GT, but I'm fairly certain it will fit any 94-04 model with automatic transmission and the original shifter.
Openscad file is attached.  Licensed for non-commercial use.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: I'm printing on glass without a raft. This leaves the bottom surface extremely smooth (notice the glare/reflection in the photos). I went with 0.3mm layers for speed. I'm hoping the part will last another 20 years, so 100% infill, ABS

The original is 1 solid part, with 2 other parts fit around it and glued/melted together. To avoid separating those other parts, I created my model in 2 parts which are inserted and then glued together. 1 - Print the pieces out. If you print the smaller piece with bright plastic, you can skip painting it. 2 - The little tab on the smaller part is the gear indicator. Paint this part. 3 - Insert the smaller part. Start by sliding the indicator tab into place through the big oval hole. Then align the black part. 4 - Slide the large printed piece in from either end (P or 1). As it slides past the smaller printed piece, make sure the larger piece is on top. Keep sliding it until the circular holes align. 5 - From the back side, super glue the two printed pieces together. These pieces should get stuck together, but remain free to slide back and forth in the channel they are in. 6 - Let the glue dry then reassemble the car. 7 - Test it. Make sure the gap is covered when the selector is in P or 1. Make sure the indicator properly shows which gear the car is in. Step 3 Step 4 Step 5. The is the view from the back side. Step 6 - reassembled Step 7 - test it before putting your tools away

This is a remix of Emil Hallgrens Hood enclosure. I wanted to not use any screws on the frame and i modified it to be able to handle my PI holder on the right side of the printer. I also put in a lid on the design and gave it hinges and a handle bar.
The top brakets is glued on the 4mm Acrylic making it a frame the bottom brakets is attached the same way as Emil's is.
The height of the acrylic is 22cm the width might need to be amended for your printer in my case back is 38,5cm and the sides top is 38cm and bottom 37,7cm the lid is 36,5x36,5cm.
The back acrylic have a 12mm cutout at the bottom 9,7cm in from both sides.

Printer:

Velleman Vertex k8400

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,21mm

Infill:

30%

Notes: I used minor supports. Think it is however possible to print them without.

comments.text:
I've an issue with the space for the plexi glasses. I measure there is a gap of only 3.5 mm instead ~4 mm. So it is really hard to mount the glasses in the parts. The other is that the corners spread the side legs (which directs to the top or lower parts) so the will not fit any more at the end and a small air gab is shown.
I used 4mm Plexi Glass parts. I printed on Vertex K8400 and the quality of the printouts are looking good. But I have no choice at the moment to check them against the real layout.
Is it true that the 3,5 mm gap is deliberated designed?

comments.text: M5 hex bolt and a nylon locking nut. Im not 100% shure right of the bat on how long they are. I think i used 40mm but i am not 100% on that. Can check for you when i get home. It is a tight fit to get it in so if you use to long bolts they wont be able to be put in due to the angle of the plastic top design. PS on a side note.... for the lid bolt and nut make shure you use shimmer mainly on the acrylic side. the wider the better to dispurse the pressure force so it dont put cracks on the acrylic as easy as the bolt does by its own. And not to much force off cource ;)

comments.text: What you do is just glue top part of the frame against the acrylic. Simplest. What i used is a Loctite super glue that is for plastic. It is a activator based glue that is heat tolerable up to a surtain level. There is epoxy based glues that work also. but that Loctite glue i found works good and it dont degrade like many other glues does when exposed to higher air heat. But the glue isnt really exposed for allot of it anyway so is a little over kill maybe.

Le trou de l'écrou de la vis trapézoïdale est très(trop? :) ) serré, il vaut mieux avoir une pince-étau pour rentrer l'écrou. Les explications du "comment ça marche" sont sur le design de Ouinche que je n'ai fait que retoucher. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:518773

English

This is a remix of Ouinche's Z anti-wooble for 8mm trapezoidal leadscrews such as the ones sold on http://www.reprap-france.com/produit/1234568281-lot-de-2-sets-visecrou-trapezoidales-8mm (the technical drawing in also among the thing's files for you to double-check the dimensions ...) Instructions :
Print 2 anti-wooble
You'll need 8x M3 15mm screws and nuts to fasten the hole for the leadscrew nut is very tight, be prepared to use pliers (ideally locking pliers...) For an explanation of why/how this is working, check Ouinche original design http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:518773
It did the job for me !

author: tunxorzz

description.text:
A simple charging stand for the Pebble Time Round.
Works for Pebble Time and Pebble Time Steel, too.

This is all the parts you need to upgrade your duplicator 4/4x to a hotend printer.
This takes a lot of weight of the printing head and allows you to print faster and reduce printer wear. Parts to buy.
  • 2 x 24 volt E3D or equivalent hotends. I used an ebay imports myself. But I did need to use my old heaters and thermocouples as the others didn't work for me. Kit will need to include hotend heat sinks, fans, fan mounts, 2mm ID pipe and push fits and the head end.
  • 2x M6 x 30mm nozzle throats. Don't get rid of your old throats as you'll need them at the stepper motors (see picture and you'll notice a thread going right up to the gear and bearing). You need longer ones because the hotends need the extra thread into them. If you could adjust the bed up further then you wouldn't need them because the heaters wouldn't need to sit so low.
  • 2 x Aluminium extruder Mk8 upgrade kits (left and right type). This is a great upgrade anyway but you'll need this so that you have a M6 thread to attach the hotend pipe to the stepper motor extruders.
  • Gear upgrade, this is the best gear to use as others can over squeeze the filament and jam the filament in the pipe/head.
  • 2 x M6 couplers- to attach the hotend pipe to the motor/extruder parts. Screw in old nozzle throat up to the extruder gear and bearing then screw on M6 coupler and then add the push fit (see picture)
  • 2 x 30mm 24Volt fans. These are for the cooling duct.
  • 1 x M3 to 25-30mm screw. This is for the head stop plate (see picture)
    • Printing parts
  • 1 x head stop. Removing the stepper motors from the head means that the y-axis stop switch has nothing to press against (see picture).
  • 1 x Remote extruder mount - This allows the motors to mount to the back of the printer
  • 1 x Hotend Cable Mount - Holds the cables in place at the head end. Old cable mount is redundant.
  • 2-4 x - Fan guards. Because the fans are small it is very easy the break them. Guards save money.
  • Cooling duct. The hotends do need a cooling duct. This duct glues in place with a bit of hot glue or something.
  • Door latch - the cooling duct does stick up further than the door. The latch is to hold the door during the print start sequence. Depending on size of print the door can then be put down to keep the heat in.
    • MUST
    You must change the head moving speed to 150mm/s on travel and retract about 3mm so that the filament doesn't oozing when moving. Don't retract more than 3mm as this will not help. Only moving fast will happy but be careful not to move too fast. Good luck will balancing your two printer heads as this is never fun on a dual head printer.

Printer:

Duplicator 4x

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

10%

Notes: 3 shells is a good idea. Cooling duct does require support. PVA glue makes an amazing surface to print on. I mix 4:1 glue:water. Water washable pva glue and water painted onto the heated bed @ 65degs works amazing.

The DC connector is a power jack found on Ebay. http://www.ebay.com/itm/221939865049?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT The LED strips are also from Ebay. After printing the original Makerbot Botmobile and having trouble finding the right motor, gear and battery combo I decided to redesign the drive train and some other components in order to make it easier for everyone to get a functional Botmobile up and running. Video of the brush version of the car in action: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=22fwVmX2GA8 Full credit for the original design goes to the guys from Makerbot Changes & Upgrades for the 2013 Version:
  • Drivetrain re-designed for the use with standard, of the shelf 280 brush as well as brushless motors
  • Drive gears modified to be fully printable and support the stronger motors
  • Body changed to accommodate 2S LiPo Packs
  • Additional mounting points added to the body to make the chassis more rigid and prevent the 2 body parts and the interior from separating
  • Steering updated to allow for better control and tighter turns
  • Receiver slot enlarged and additional RX brackets provided to allow installation of a larger variety of receivers.

  • Updated assembly manual with full parts and source list

    All parts are tested and print fine on a Replicator 2X (ABS) using Makerware.

Please refer to the downloadable Manual. Update 22/2/2017
  • Part list in the manual updated with working links and new references. Have fun
    • Update 13/7/2013
  • Model for a rubber tire uploaded. Experimental: as I do not have the possibility to print rubber this model is subject to confirmation by other users.
    • Update 11/7/2013:
  • Final Manual uploaded
    • Update 10/7/2013:
  • Manual V2 uploaded with added assembly instructions for steering, gearbox and rear axle

title: Prusa I3 (6mm Aluminum frame) spool holder

description.text:
I printed the "Prusa i3 spool holder by n00bz0rz"
Unfortunately it didn't fit my aluminium frame, so i had to make a spacer for a tight fit and more stability.(Didn't want to waste it)
I also added a spool adapter for spools with 100mm inner diameter.
Spool adapter has a M6 threaded hole for bolt to rest in the holder( 2 x M6x40mm bolts)
A washer(s) for a bit clearance from the spool adapter to the spool holder.(i used 2)
Also made a collar(for Quick release) with a space a M4 nut and bolt for fastening(locking)

Attempting to make a keychain that is truly 3 dimensional. I have created this frame using OpenScad and linear extruded the helix shape. However, I am having trouble printing this frame. If I turn supports on, an extruded triangle is created as the supports create a wall to support the upper tier as well as within the columns. Without supports, only the bottom triangle can be partially printed.

OpenScad, Isosceles Triangles and Trig I created a sphere and then three linear extruded circles of a certain height and twist.
Each circle was placed as a vortex on an isosceles triangle and extruded. This sphere and helix design was modularized and then each module was translated and rotated to create the frame of an isosceles triangle and columns. while the first vortex was at 0,0 and the second vortex was at (length, 0) the third vortex was found using trig, the 60 degree angle, and the length.

title: Parametric Customizable Foam Core Corner Brackets

description.text:
I was going to experiment with putting a foam core wall around my 3d printer to see if it would cut out some of the noise in the other room.  I  initially made this just a simple part, but carried it further & made it parametric with quite a few variables.  You can make 90 degree corners with 2 or 3 connections.  You can vary most of the individual dimensions of this part.  You can create either 90, 120, 72, 60, 45, 40, 36 & 30 degree corners.  This allows you to connect foam core or some other sturdy flat material & make 3 sided, 4 sided, 5 sided, 6 sided, 8 side, 9 sided, 10 sided or 12 sided structures.  I am only using it for 4 sided with what I needed, but added the others while it was fresh in my mind.  You might have to fine tune your printing for the 3 corner version as it prints at a 45 degree to eliminate having to add support.  My print of that version came out a little rough, but quite usable.  I added 6mm brim for that print.
To use this with another material besides foam core, change the Gap variable for the width of your material & add a little extra width for clearance if you need it.  I used 4.5mm to use with the foam core I have.  All the customizable variables are documented as to their purpose.  You can also open this in the Customizer.

This is a simple desktop sharpie marker holder.  Absolutely essential for someone who owns multiple sharpies and needs easy access to them on a regular basis.  It also looks cool sitting on your desk!

It is highly recommended (especially if you're customizing this item) that you tap the "Open in Customizer" button, set the hole count to 1, and print a test piece first. This design depends on two things:
  • A tight fit for the markers to prevent wobbliness. Measurements are precise, and not all printers and markers are the same.
  • Balance; for style, the markers are on a 5 degree angle, and there is a foot to prevent it from tipping over.

I have included a .scad file so you can customize this design to your needs. Including holding other sized writing utensils or stick-like items. You can set:
  • Number of markers to hold
  • Diameter of each holder
  • Spacing between holders
  • Thickness of all surfaces
  • Angle to hold the items on
    • Note If you adjust the angle to be higher, you might need to extend the base so the holder doesn't tip over.
I have also pre-rendered a 4,6 and 8 count holder for those who are not familiar or comfortable with OpenSCAD.

Please check out these other customizable items by me: Trendy Desktop Bins

Using Schlem's "incher" drop in module as a base, I made this drop in for the Koroll 6x6 MED format camera.... its a 'bowtie' style shutter...mainly for good looks...;)
I added the 6x 4.5 mask as a option...as 6x 4.5 gets a few more shots per roll...these also slide out for 6x6 use.
Polished body looks great...
worked out to have 50mm focal length and using a 0.26mm pinhole aperture has a F-stop of f192...have shot a test roll, but not processed it yet...
Work in progress...

Printer:

Zortrax M200

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes: will need to test fit main module to body for press fit

I have been using the Tech Shop Filament Guide which works well but I was having problems with the filament un-spooling or jumping off the spool. This guide uses an 8" piece of PFTE tubing (4mm OD/ 2mm ID) to guide the filament which keeps it on the spool. The tubing reaches part way over the top of the spool. This design installs best on printers with an extruded aluminum chassis but may also be used with other printers using the two 5mm mounting holes. Since I installed this guide, I have not had any filament unwind or jump the spool.
Update 1 7-19-2016: I added another filament guide design that uses 1/4" PFTE. This works well if you are using my design for an Airtight Filament Canister below:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1332650
The new filament guide allows you to connect the canister directly to the filament guide. I've also found that the larger tubing is good when using a spool. It has a bit less drag.

Display with leds created for http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1086818 (oni skull hollowed). Print torii twice. It has areas for wires and 2 leds. Lanterns were drilled and string was added. I feel like I want to reprint those in white and somehow add a more oriental design to them. But I broke the glass plate for my printer when I went to wash it.... Base has areas for wires that will hold 2 AAA batteries. I managed to easily wedge in the wires to the battery terminals. Tag is just glued in place. I was going to add a switch for the leds but I needed it for a future project so I made the tag to hide the holes.

I loved the look of the oni skull so much that I wanted a nice way to display it. And leds make
everything better.

This is a fan duct for a Geeetech I3 Pro C duel extruder. It works with 40mm X 40mm fans. It just slides onto the metal duel extruder bracket that came with my printer. I scaled up the original model before I uploaded it because I usually have a lot of shrinkage. It's a little loose. I printed this in PLA because I had no other kind of filament. If it works out well I'll probably buy some nylon to print it out of. READ NEXT
I just wanted to update this with more information. As a newbee to 3D printing I wasn't aware my printer had to be calibrated after I assembled it, so I scaled up the fan duct to anticipate probable shrinkage, but it wasn't shrink it was just incorrect calibration. So if anyone prints this at this size, it will be loose. You may want to scale it down by .98
NEXT
I just added the Parasolid file, just in case any one might want to improve on this model.
NEXT

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1337672

This is a mount I made for the Arduino Mega 2560. Ramps board is on top in the picture but the mount attaches to the arduino via swedging plastic posts with a soldering iron. Shown on my Prusa i2. This replaced the melzi v1.0 and previous mount in my collection.

This is a 200mm MTM racing quad. It is a tight fit to get everything inside so not a great beginner build. The arms and two central plates are designed to be made out of carbon fiber and are available for purchase here. Arms to clear 6" props are also available.
https://armattanproductions.com/pages/kit_detail/57 Might make a few more changes to the dome for access to the USB port and to fit the VTX or any recording camera a bit better. Bunch of pictures here.
http://imgur.com/a/bFTxA The assembly goes something like this. The arms spacer and baseplates are bolted together with the two inside holes on each arm with the heads of the bolts facing down. The bottom dome has the XT60 connector and wiring installed and then the PDB is installed. Camera is mounted to the upper dome. The arms and center plates are now attached to the bottom dome and any motor wiring can be completed. Install the flight controller and figure out where you are going to fit everything else this is a tight fit.

comments.text:
I have an Aurora A3, but it has injection molded X-carriage part, not 3D Printed like the other parts.
Your design is different than what I have, but it looks like it fits the same.
Did you A3 x-carriage come as injection-molded and Is this a one-to-one functional replacement for it?
OK, re-read your description. It's not functionally identical. hmm...
comments.author: DaHai8

comments.text: like i said in the description this raises the print head by about 4mm upwards due to the through bolt design. i too have the injection molded part but it developed a tilt forward i could detect when it rubbed across the print. so i remixed this design to fit. You can compensate for the rise by raising your print bed.. i'm not sure if the supplied screws are long enough and you might need longer springs. get out your tape measure and see. This mod coincided when i added a sheet of glass to the print bed so very little adjustment was needed.. anyways give it print and try it. don't like it you haven't lost much
comments.author: DaHai8

comments.text:
Thanks for the quick reply!
I know a couple people looking for this part including myself. I'll give yours a try and perhaps reverse engineer mine and post it for another option.
Thanks again!
comments.author: redcat

comments.text: ok looked at and measured and if you have 25mm (threaded) long screws you should have enough screw length at the bed. Have you got more that 4mm of thread availible? personally i wouldn't bother re-engineering the old one when there is already one available (mine). the printer could be massively improved elsewhere so use your effort there. like a adjustable z stop. the injection molded part failure is the back plate. and the way it holds the bearings. too much slope. although in hindsight the quick fix is drilling holes for zip ties to hold the bearings. let us know how you go
comments.author: DaHai8

comments.text:
I've got a sheet of PrintBite on order. It's not quite 4mm, but it should make up enough difference to not need longer bed screws.
Thanks!

comments.author: Ccc11223

comments.text: I love my fisker. The car is amazing to drive. The reliability has been very good with no mechanical issues at all. The only issues I have had are with the CIU (The main center display), slowness etc. Karma automotive has done a good job with software updates but service locations are limited. If you find one to buy make sure it has the inspection done so it qualifies for the 2Yr warranty offered by Karma automotive.The latest software 530 has made some very good improvements to the car and Karma but is working on a fix for some CIU issues. Let me know if you get one. I'm on FiskerBuzz as Sterling500
comments.author: sterling500

title: iPhone 6 mount for Jeep Wrangler YJ

description.text:
I needed a way to hold my iPhone 6 in my 1995 Jeep Wrangler YJ for navigation.  This holder grips the dashboard (and the defroster opening) and is easily installed and removed without any fasteners.
Print the two parts and super glue them together as in the photos.  Done.
(Print the phone holder standing upright.  Print the clip laying on one side -- which is not how it's shown in the stl file.)
Update:  I added the Google Sketchup file for the phone holder component, so you can customize it to fit other phones.
Update 2:  I forgot something about cars, especially Jeeps:  They do tend to vibrate a bit.  Since the phone is not a tight fit in the holder, it buzzes around in there a lot.  I'm noodling on a fix for this -- for right now, a piece of sticky-backed felt should take up the slack nicely.  (Later that day:  The stick-on felt pad works perfectly, so I'm calling it done!)
Update 2016 04 07:  I'm seeing some warping of the clip part as it sits in the hot sun.  The grip on the dashboard is a bit looser now, but it still works fine.  Will keep updating as things develop.
Update 2016 06 03:  After a few days in the 80's it's a bit more warped, but still working fine.  Of course, I took my doors and top off.  You know, because Jeep.  If you insist on keeping your Jeep sealed up, well, I can't be responsible for the results.

comments.text: I am having trouble getting the dash connector to attach to the phone, what am I missing?
comments.author: carlswanson60

comments.text: You need to print two parts:  The dash connector and the phone holder.  Then super-glue them together so they align as in the photos.  Does that help?
comments.author: carlswanson60

comments.text:
I'm not a big fan of super glue, I will drill and use machine screws.
Thanks for getting back to me.d
comments.author: brotherjethro

comments.text: I agree about the super glue, especially when it's holding my $800 phone!  If I designed this over again, I would create interlocking features on the two parts so that the glue only had to hold them together, but the features would support all of the load.  This would also ensure correct alignment of the parts.
comments.author: carlswanson60

comments.text: Love the idea!  Would you be willing to share the SKP for the hanger?  I need to make something for my son's YJ that will hold both his phone as well as a trail CB mic, and would like to make some changes (with 100% attribution, and not for sale!)

I've searched everywhere, but can't find the original.  There are tools that you can use to import an STL -- if nothing else, you could use these to get measurements and start over.

author: colebusiness

title: Customizable Shaft Buddy: A shaft coupler/adapter generator

description.text: Overview: This customizer can generate a shaft coupler that accepts a shaft (female) or acts as one (male) on either end for a variety of shaft shapes (hex, square, round (with set screws), and round with one or two flats). "Sleeve" mode: In addition to generating the usual two-sided couplers, it has a special mode to adapt a smaller shaft of one form to a significantly larger one -- it can create a single-form "sleeve" that goes around the smaller shaft, boosting it up to the larger shaft size. To use this mode, set shaft 1 to male, shaft 2 to female, and make sure that shaft 1 is significantly larger than shaft 2. You can disable this special behavior by setting disable_single_form to "yes". Background: A while back, I wrote a simple set-screw coupler generator for round shafts. Then I needed to convert a 5/16" round shaft with a 2mm keyway to a 1/2" hex shaft, so I wrote a one-off SCAD script to do that. Then I needed yet another coupler, so I wrote that one too. Then I decided I never wanted to design another coupler again, so I wrote this to hopefully solve the problem forever. Update Jan 2018: Added an option to force set screws for non-round shafts (e.g. hex, square, etc.).

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Silver

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: Set infill according to the strength needed. Important: Depending on your settings, you may need to flip your coupler upside down to avoid unnecessary overhangs. If you do this, you shouldn't ever need supports.

description.text: I use this to collect small pieces of garbage in my workshop; packaging, stripped wire, etc.  Because this unit can be customized, you can set the size and density of the walls to suit your needs and use them for whatever you'd like!

Download the .scad file or even easier, hit the "Open in Customizer" button to customize this to your needs. You can set:
  • The diameter of the base and top.
  • The height.
  • Thickness of all parts.
  • Number of pillars.
  • If you want pillars in one direction, or both.
  • How much the pillars should twist.
I have also uploaded some pre-rendered if you want to download and print a unit immediately, but I highly recommend opening the customizer and putting in your own values!

Please check out these other customizable items by me: Sharpie Marker Holder

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
In my quest for the perfect printer, here's a new design. It's a tiltable wheel carriage for my Kossel Mini allowing to level the arms and ensure the effector is flat.
Enhanced impression quality but didn't fix my problem again, which came from my auto bed leveling procedure. Anyway, this design exists and works fine with manual calibration. Enjoy ! Print with supports disabled and use a 3mm drill to make holes.

author: jnaulet

description.text:
Sometimes there are programs that make "adjustments" to the scale of  your designs. Here is a digital ruler that you can import to your program and will help you in the verificatioin of the right size of your part.
I got information that when downloaded, it was just a square of plastic. I re-uploaded a revised version of the ruler (Sorry). Please leave a comment if it works for you!

comments.text:
Hello everyone
in fact, I tried to print the ruler and I get the same piece of plastic with no numbers, probably because of the height and size of the numbers that are too small for the resolution of almost all machines of FFF technique.
As I mentioned in the description, this is a tool to help you to scale easity parts once they are in the printing program (simplify3D, Cura, MatterControl, etc.) .The idea is to place the ruler under the part you are going to scale and easily check if the resized part meets your desired sizes.Once you have the expected size, simply remove the ruler and print your scaled part.
